original_title: Odd Retrocomputer Had a Graphics Coprocessor
original_content:
[Noels Retro Lab] scored an unusual 1980s vintage computer sold in Japan and Spain. The Seconinsa FM-7 appears to be a popular Fujitsu Japanese computer altered to fit the Spanish market. They seem to be pretty rare, at least in our part of the world. The outside appearance was very nice for the time, with a large keyboard and plenty of expansion ports. But the board has an unusual feature considering the era  dual CPUs. One 6809 executed your program, and another 6809 handled graphics output. You can see the machine in the video below.
There are two 32K ROMs, but the machine specifications claim only 48K. After dumping the ROMs, it turns out one of the ROMs has two copies of the same data. You can imagine they might not want to decode the entire address space. It could be that they needed 16K of space for other devices.
It wasnt just the ROMs. The video RAM is pretty strange, too, as [Noel] explains. There are even some static RAMs the computer doesnt claim. It appears these act as communication pipes between the two CPUs. In fact, it turns out that even the keyboard has its own 4-bit CPU, so the machine actually has a total of 3 CPUs!
This was a heavy-duty design for the time it was built. [Noel] wanted to fire it up, but he had to figure out the cables since the computer didnt have any with it. Some clever repurposing of stock cables provided monochrome video output. Color display was a bit more complicated, but not impossible.
[Noel] winds the video up with some history of the companies behind the machine. The Spanish government wanted to use the FM-7 in the classroom, but the program failed to materialize. Want to see what it was like to program the thing? Heres the Basic reference manual (in Spanish). Most of the documentation for the machine is either in Spanish or Japanese.
While this certainly is a rare computer, at least theres a record of its existence. If you want to see what a Japanese computer looked like a few decades earlier, check out the FACOM 128B.
title: 「1980年代のレアな日本製コンピューター、Seconinsa FM-7の特徴と仕様」
body: [Noels Retro Lab]は、日本とスペインで販売された珍しい1980年代のヴィンテージコンピューターを手に入れた。Seconinsa FM-7は、スペイン市場に合わせて改造された人気のある富士通の日本のコンピューターのようだ。外観は当時にしては非常に素晴らしく、大型のキーボードと多くの拡張ポートがある。しかし、このボードは当時に考えると珍しい機能を持っている。二つのCPUが搭載されており、一つはプログラムの実行、もう一つはグラフィック出力を担当している。ROMが2つあり、スペックは48Kとのことだが、実際にはデータの2つのコピーがあることが判明した。また、ビデオRAMも特異な仕様であり、キーボードにも独自のCPUが搭載されているため、このマシンは実際には3つのCPUを持っていることが判明した。このコンピューターは重厚なデザインであり、機能も充実している。
